question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

 Evaluate the following integral.

$\int_{0}^{1} \frac{2x+3}{(x+1)^{2}}\, dx$
sols:
We proceed by partial fractions. First, we solve for the constants in

$\frac{2x+3}{(x+1)^{2}} = \frac{A}{x+1} + \frac{B}{(x+1)^{2}} = \frac{A(x+1) + B}{(x+1)^{2}}$

As the denominators above are equal, the numerators must also be equal
and so

$2x + 3 = A(x+1) + B$

Now, plugging in $x=-1$ into the above gives

$2(-1)+3 = A(-1+1) + B$

and simplifying gives $B = 1$. Plugging in $x=0$ into the above yields

$3 = 2(0) + 3 = A(0+1) + B = A + B = A + 1$

and so $A = 2$. Therefore, we have

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1} \frac{2x+3}{(x+1)^{2}}\, dx &= \int_{0}^{1}\frac{2}{x+1} \, dx +\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(x+1)^{2}} \, dx \\
&= \left. 2\ln|x+1|\right|_{0}^{1}  - \left. (x+1)^{-1}\right|_{0}^{1} \\
&= 2\ln|1+1| - 2\ln|0+1|  -((1+1)^{-1} - (0 + 1)^{-1}) \\
&= 2\ln(2) -\frac{1}{2} + 1 \\
&= 2\ln(2) +\frac{1}{2} 
\end{align*}

completing the question.
